hyperbole luther vsually frequented schooles whereby doth embase freewill nothing el title forged fantasie amongest naturall cause touchyng luther frequentyng hyperbolicall speaches admit would somewhat yeld vnto yet sithence scripture selfe doth altogether vnacquaynte selfe kynde figure reseruyng alwayes truth thing waywardnesse men vouchsafe luther expresse certeine wordes sharpe vehemencie speachoutragious hyperbolicall speaches popish doctrine whenas selues meanewhiles either blockyshnesse doe marke malice reforme onely ye friuolous barrennes word also outragious excesse speaches wherewith whole doctrine swarmeth euery maruell luther inueighyng agaynst monstruous outrage doctrine waxe somewhat whotte sometymes certeine vehement maner speakyng man adiudge worthy reprehended respect would fayne haue man required hee vouchsafe impute heate ye vehemēcie god spirite purpose good pleasure directeth instrumentes lysteth hee yet least bethinke selfe great importaunce cause wherein luther trauayled tyme weighe aduisedly manifold darkenesse errours season withall enter deépe consideration vnmeasurable iniuries aduersaries luther mainteyne iust quarell person freewill playnly perfectly whole diminished otherwise attribute freédome vnto remayneth way definition ye expounde difference betwixt state condition first man fall latter state condition fall dismember graunt vnto certeine vnperfect dregges thereof onely neither luther vary much hereinfreewill weakened fall must obserued distinctiō action ye yeld distinctiō thereunto vtter playnly distinctly kynde libertie meane thynges settle ought taken word freewill emporteth action man lyfe ought referred withall vnlose crabbed knottes equiuocatiōs wherewith ye seéke entrappe truth whereas action man lyfe one sort kynde wherof proceédyng nature selfe naturall others altogether faultie corrupt others politique apperteinyng maners morall called good agayne spirituall consiste worshyppyng god behoued make manifest vnto v whiche action meane speake first kynde certes euē vnto ye law cōmon nature selfe fastened boūde necessitie wherby bereft ye greatest part freédome freédome bee mighty man wil preserue mā neuer neéde sleépe alwayes watchfull neuer sicke alwayes healthy neuer receaue sustenaūce disgest foode receauednaturall action prouide houshold carefull selfe family busied abroad rest home enioy ye commō ayre lyue dye performe dueties apperteinyng man lyfe whereunto forcibly drawen course nature much allurement constrainte necessitieciuill action belongyng vse common lyfe come vse handlyng ciuill trade forreine discipline dutiefull action consideration kynde dayly frequented man lyfe whiche albeit luther confesse many thynges conteined subiect vnto freewill yet otherwise graunt thereunto euen selfe ye vnderstandyng mynde many tymes deceaued defrauded freédome altogether ouerthrowen yet doe cause vtterly extinguishe freédome wrappe vp entangle mynde spoyle reason coūsell dispossesse mā frō aunciēt inheritaunce choyse howsoeuer cruell outrage sinne hath weakened wasted sinewes strength nature beyng well created first yet remayneth neuerthelesse naturall power soule onely renewed spirite also regenerate respect action especially wherof made mention beforeactions merely spirituall question remoued action belong naturall common conuersation life apperteine spirituall worshyppyng god concerne kyngdome christ easily discerne freewill receaueth grace though garnished neuer gorgeous tittle hath besides glorious tittle onely nothyng el whereby may defende selfe seruile bondage rayse selfe vp attaine true freéedome saluation doe speake freédome osorius properly opposite constrainte compulsary violēce wherof vaunte vayne naturall power reasonable soule whiche seéke shake ne yet man beyng regenerated disable finally yet action wherewith sensible lyfe beautified speake affection ascribed spirituall lyfe person regenerate christfiue kyndes question whereupon accordyng fiue distinction afore mentioned many seuerall kyndes question arise auoydyng confusion must seuerally distinguished 1 questfirst question moued freédome nature pure sounde fall adam doth know state pure freéaug vpon worde apostle serm 2 bee doubted man freewill absolutely perfect first creation man sinne lost freedome altogether august 2 questsecundarely question bee remoued ouer substaunce part man wherewith mynde endued vnderstandyng appetite questiō whether man called freé fall adam vtterly extinct substaunce aunswere ambrose ambros callyng gē tils lib 1 cap 3 iudgemēt corrupted deede vtterly taken away agayne deuill spoyle man vtterly bereft soundenesse integritie although man vnderstandyng parte soule miserably corrupted originall sinne yet altogether abolished remayneth freédome doe freé call respect thynges either naturally carryed motion without iudgement brute beastes whiche forced coaction agaynst nature stone therefore spoken appeareth wherewith naturally endued respect essentiall naturall disposition thereof doth alwayes remayne man nature corrupt soeuer yea remayneth wise hauyng alwayes freé voluntary operation naturall cause without forreine coaction vnlesse hindered naturall sensibilitie also capacitie iustine tearmeth heauenly thyngescapacitie 〈 nonlatin alphabet 〉 holpē augustine wordes seéme emporte iudgement speakyng defence freewill vseth wordesaugust epist 46 beleeue sayth hee holy scripture grace god without helpe whereof man neither turne vnto god profite god agayne secōd epistle valentin catholicke faith doth neither deny freewill applyable good life badd life doth esteeme therof highly though value without grace god either turne frō euill good perseuer stedfast good attaine euerlasting goodnes whereas feareth left may fainte decay c agayne placeaugust de grat lib • b lib 1 cap 15 confesse sayth hee alwayes free v alwayes good maner sayd bee alwayes freé must learned augustine either free righteousnesse sayth bondslaue sinne euill free sinne handmayd righteousnesse good c appeareth therefore twofold freédome augustine man freedome twofold freedome must cōstrued man alwayes freé good thynges euill thynges ought conceaue freédome wise hath power owne strength make choyse good euill namely spirituall matter aduersaries doe dreame accordyng augustine interpretation whē naught owne disposition naught good guided grace vnwillyngly voluntaryly without compulsionhow freewill must taken yet freé notwithstandyng alwayes whether good bad bycause alwayes voluntary neuer constrained much touchyng propertie naturall disposition mās deny seemeth conceite euen one deny man reasonable creature seé cause reason may sequestred man ought seuered reason two thynges vnited together certeine naturall affinitie mutually linked together inseparable knot reasonable soule reason cā neither performe exployte without enterprise thyng aduisedly without guidyng reason therefore iudgement belongeth properly reason worke apperteineth properly whether good euil one wherof respecteth ye substaūce peculiar disposition therof liuely reason enclosed within certeine limittes boūdes hath proper peculiar obiectes vnable rayse selfe beyond cōpasse naturall vitall cause vnles enlightened euē beyng straighted wtin ye limittes boūdes naturall cause hath power selfe either attēpt atchieue spirituall good thing vnlesse holpen 3 questfor much therefore reason doe owne right exercize actiuitie dominiō naturall thyngs onely said lawfull prouinces hereof springeth thyrd question whether freédome able selfe embrace eschewe thyngs gouerned externall sens reason whereunto aunswere easiewhether free thynges whiche ruled reason bee doubted mynde wil two freewill deriued yet still reteine certein sparckes freédome euen forlorne nature mynde certeine sorte able thinke purpose take counsell iudge allow disallowthe maister sentence 2 booke dist 2425 like maner also doth enioy certeine freédome thynges whereunto sense reason direct able wil chuse chuse desire forsake stay purpose chaunge moue hether thether certein maner exercize selfe kynde externall discipline say worke externall honest action agreable law god eschew cōtrary thyng besides many thynges doe approue true well sundry example ethnicke people also whole politicall estate doth verifie true also performed without god guidyng thyng nazienzen notably aduertize expresse oratiōnazienzenus oratione know sayth hee goale attained quyuernes person successe battell prowesse conquest atchieued fighting yet safe sure roade alwayes skilfull saylers commaundement onely worke god geue victorie cōduct shippe safety vnto happie hauen c much actiōs referred properly politique reason diuinitie concerne luther discourse much shalbe neédelesse bestow great labour herein fourthly approche somewhat neare thynges peculiar4 quest belong chiefly doctrine deuines worke righteousnesse vnlesse god geue free passage whereby may perceaue mās one tyme freé captiuemans free free witte freé doe euill much pursuyng lust voluntary delight neédeth forreine coactiō worke euill whiche also luther doth deny respect freé good vnlesse set libertie god grace speake augustine word vnlesse guided euery good actiō doyng speakyng thinkyng iolly fellowes stoutely yeld man equall freédome good euill corruptiō nature yet might graunted also sort interpreted accordingly meane regenerated tollerable enough neither luther agaynst whose discourse freewill tendeth wherof state luther discourse consisteth witte touchyng spirituall motion action touchyng heauenly thynges workes apperteinyng vnto god touchyng spirituall righteousnesse inward worshyppyngs fayth must necessitie hold rule fast whiche teacheth albeit man nature fallen integritie excellent absolute freédome yet ouerthrowen miserable state seruilitie whiche proper brute beastes neither altogether contrarietie may demeane selfe suffering also aunswere luther luther owne wordes witte diuers seuerall sortes common phrase speach diuers seuerall respectes respect worke selfe whenas occupyeth place instrument toole doth made euen tooles matter whereunto applyed haue relation efficient cause workeman whose vse serueth steéde toole respect man demeaneth selfe altogether sufferyngly respect procuryng god grace whence issueth motion good worketh nothyng simply obeyeth suffereth good worke man elles instrument holy ghostmans taken instrument yet free neuerthelesse voluntary deéde bycause moued whether soeuer moued owne accord yet instrument notwithstandyng bycause thynges well done neither cause selfe sparcke cause respect worker seruaunt rather handmayde onely whose seruice spirite gayne say euery way yeldeth ye whole interest aswell former hinder partes god whether osori declaryng god worketh v bryng passe thyngs accordyng good pleasure finde meane thyng paraduenture betwixt whiche may attribute freewill euen agayne shall driuen backe whereas may heare paule pronounce god geueth increase onely originall good encrease also well doyng accomplishyng proceédyng success also flow holy ghost man thē say god grace doth worke v osorius obiection purpose serueth freewill naturally engraffed within v beyng holpen grace sayd doe thyng shall thinke ought accōpted respect partener workyng good worke aūswere wherofaunswere would wishe harkē wordes speake vnto augustine true osori whatsoeuer good worke wrought v prayse thereof ought redounde wholy freewill god grace performeth whatsoeuer performed v godly worthy prayse wordes augustine emporte true humble confession doth require v say referre vnto god yet grace god doth worke whiche proper selfe selfe onely workyng v without freewill agayne neither worketh together freewill portion prayse rewarde bee ascribed freewill whatsoeuer due vnto god therefore augustine booke de gratia libero arbit • affirmeaugust de grat lib arbit neither grace without freewill freewill without grace sufficient confesse true either worketh cō fesse yet certeine seuerall sort grace god worketh helpeth man freewill yet worketh wise neuer wrought doth helpe freewill beyng neuer holpen freewill furthermore doth helpe alwayes freé helpe fine whēas god grace doth worke effectually helpyng mās willotherwise worketh god spirite otherwise man freewill diuersitie yet worketh mās freewill stā dyng neéde helpe freewill meanes rather vsing ye seruice therof state freewill farre otherwise freewill worketh together god spirite commaundyng seruice tyme alwayes wantyng assistaunce one wherof perceaue efficacie cause worketh seruice onely instrumentwill doth nothyng good thing whē holpen applyed moreouer doth worke effectually god grace directyng yea freély bycause worketh voluntaryly yet doth neuer attempt good thyng selfe without directiō grace neither meanes otherwise holpen neuer helpeth grace wrought holpen yea also wrought worketh chuse worke necessitie euen seruauntes respect birth freé beyng commaūded maisters bounde vnto must obey whether nill necessitie like maner fareth men freewilles albeit stand plight alwayes carried freé motiō say voluntary motion thynges whatsoeuer yet farre able enough owne power prosecute purposed imagination would wishe selues many true man naturall strength bee freé bond thē strong enough wickednesse stormes raysed agaynst luther neédelesse also consideryng doth frankely oftentymes many place professe playne wordes man mynde defendours freewill taken booke hyperaspistesbut ye great proctours freewill wont obiect sense true deéde power absolutely fully freé onely omnipotēt power god maiestie yet neuertheles call angel immortall men holy wise good though doe acknowledge god onely bee truly immortall onely wise onely good nothyng withstā deth may call men certeine maner freé aūswereaunswere angel deéde called immortall truly bycause obteined state creatour first besides also neuer lost state immortalitie wherein placed although fell frō blessednes immortalitie freédome condition state therof farre condition kynde albeit mā beginnyng created freé estate ye benefite creatour might haue reteigned still without contradiction would yet hee loase freédome paradise withall default turned blessed estate miserie freédome bondage beyng paradise much sequestred frō felicitie euen farre seéme cut freédome without grace redeémer shyppe wracke beyng made vniuersall blessednesse seé none remedy freédome must drowned withall therefore selfe thyng whiche doth open paradise beyng shut fast agaynst v must necessitie restore freédome agayne meanes brought passe force nature power owne consisteth onely grace redeémer redeémer selfe witnesseth iohns gospelliohn 8 sonne shall make free shall free deede notyng vnto v one thyng chiefly wordes state bondage except renewed grace redeémer nature nothyng freé moreouer concernyng vsuall maner speach men called good holy wisein men called holy wise must referred deseruyngs grace wholy know men haue bene accustomed bee tearmed purpose question name mē called value euery thyng sight god yet doubt yt many men may bee kinde good holy wise euen esteémed well enough howsoeuer holynesse godlynesse wisedome mē seémeth man iudgement yet nothyng whatsoeuer proceéde grace god hast thou thou hast receaued sorte aunswere touchyng freédome whiche beyng lost freewill must necessitie sticke fast cloyed ye puddle thraldome vnlesse renewed agayne god euill thinges whenas respect neither freédome also august epistle hillary may well gathered framed argument wise lyfe libertie perfect soundenesse willan argument wordes august hyllary doyng euill man sounde ergo doyng euill man freé euen taught vp augustine wordes lyfe libertie sayth soundenesse much euery man free much sound albeit striue much contention tearmes mā minded name choyse applyable towardes good euill voluntary rather freé shall erre much iudgement neither offended man say augustine doth mās freé towardes euill thinges hold meanyng augustine well wordes mynde augustine doth name man freewill couple grace calleth freé respectin sense aug calleth freewill seemeth rather bee termed voluntary thē free bycause beyng freé frō forcible constrainte bēdeth selfe voluntary motiō way whereunto directed goodnes grace euill naturall lust sense accordyng august meanyng ye confessiō auspurgh doth expoūde mās freé say yeldyng owne accord selfe bucer melancthou also also doth caluine deny doth neither striue much tearme freédomethe confession auspurgh doth learnedly also professe originall cause euill sought elles euery man owne concernyng luther doth vpon occasion sometyme expresse minde writing somewhat roughly wherein afterwards discouereth meanyng mylde phrase speach seémely conceite racke thynges onely whiche might breéde offence cloakyng meane while thynges fraudulently wipe away mislikyng doth set downe assertion thus man freé power thinke good euill thought agayne assertion luther doth deny man imagination owne inclination carried kynde naughtynesse freewill nothyng selfe sinne wise lyke heate disputation rather errour calleth freewill sometyme fayned deuised tearme bee founde deéde makyng thynges gouerned vnauoydeable necessitie vehemencie speach many men cast teéth reprochfully thencaluinus contra alb ph • gium lib 5 yet place agayne exp • undyng selfe doth graūt without hyperbolicall speéche inferiour cause freewill somewhat withall doth franckely affirme thynges beyng assisted grace hee holden excused well snatcht doe aduersaries shut fast eye blindfold selues willyngly matter well spokē neuer looke abroad liste carpe cauill euer circūspect writer whose latter diligence attentiue heédefulnes might alwayes amend ouersight escaped first either exposition iudgement thynges solon sage grewe yeares increased knowledge may bee lawfull v encrease vnderstādyng age likewise surely august could excuse errours youth neither shamed confesse age ouersight escaped penne youth vnaduisedly onely reforme ouerlickyng beare licketh whelpes also reuoke openly open graue grayheaded retractation pray pardon errours franckly doth vayne permitte bookes preiudiciall vnto whiche hee wrate beyng young manaugust de bono perseuer prosper cap 12 • 21 saying modestly selfe hee began write like learner • grounded iudgement neither perfection required luther albeit vttered somewhat first wordes otherwise common custome schooles acquainted bene partes graue deuines prye narrowly ye vnaccustomed phrase wordes much sift substaunce doctrine agreably accorded scripture truth sinceritie matter would admitte interpretation yet ought assertiō haue bene compared assertion place place finally consideration ought haue bene entent meanyng writer also first originall scope doctrine whereunto tended emported ye would examine vprightly opinion assertion mē accordyng true touchstone god truth sinisterly eiudge whether opinion pray seémeth cō ceite sounde doe aduaunce maiestie god grace whiche doe enhaunce weakenesse man nature doe make men merites workes effectes saluatiō ascribe god freé imputation iesu christ doe determine righteousnesse commeth fayth say obteyned workes law whiche spoyle freewill matter glory vpona comparison luther assertiōs papistes call mē backe true humble acknowledgement selues whiche razing euerlastyng vnchaungeable decreé god predestination doe committe success pleasure stayed stable order yet doth luther roote freewill altogether chaunceablenesse fortune doth admitte vse respect witte respect inferiour cause although respect hygher cause thynges whiche concerne saluation damnation beleueth surely force freewill ne yet chaunceablenesse fortune doe preuayle thyng much chief grounde luther doctrinethe fruite cōmoditie luther doctrine el may well affectioned indifferent reader pray cōceaue assertiō may magnifie glory god extoll omnipotencie may establishe sauetie faythfull dependyng vpon freé promise god fayth vpō worthynes merites freewill may terrifie wicked wholesome feare god may restrayne frō outrage may comfort v agaynst death lyfe yt god agaynst miserie grace infirmitie strength agaynst destruction god mercy may rayse vp godly loue embrace god fruite thyngs godly reader may easily reape doctrine let v seé side poyson osorius doth sucke fame one seéth nothyng assertiōosorius pag 151 horrible wickednes fayth shamelesse matter soone end world gone long sithēce osor wherin pythagoricall prouerbe 〈 nonlatin alphabet 〉 takē lawthe man hath spoke thinke enough harken man speake cōsider vpon groūde mā speaketh well say vnto v lēgth osorius lawes decay statute put silence science rooted learnyng extinguished trāquillitie disturbed right wrong confounded together certes haue heard man many hygh absurde speaches well doyng punishmēt threatened malefactours vayne prescribed posterity god word heauē earth sea hercules yet tush trifle yet ouer besides ensueth haynous fact horrible toung speake hart cā thinke deface ye without great perill cōmittyng horrible sacriledge speake necessitie necessitie called violēt coactiō named vndoubted assuraūce absolute infallibilitie necessitie schoolemen call consequēti • called consequētia ex hypothesi manifold consideration necessitie necessitie neither takē one onely significatiō amongest ye deuines yet amōgest ye logiciās philosopher wherof suppose nothyng ignoraunt least ought ignoraunt therof surely therefore haue employed studyes somewhat carefully ye scannyng matter haue defined necessary manerwhat necessary thyng bee altered certeine settled firme vnmoueablenes chaūged meanes whiche necessary aristotle hath se • downe two principall begynnynges one internall externall also distinction made necessitie two beginnynges neccessitie moued force internall cause inward proprietie nature thynges may called simply absolutely necessary god thynges whiche beyng chaunged emply contradiction man would say foure euen nomber foure threé seuen nomber called geometricall necessitie admitte chaunge course nature necessitie called naturall necessitie albeit bee selfe begynnyng owne motion yet consisteth simple absolute estate followeth onely vsuall course owne nature maner • fier sayd bourne necessitie sunne continually carried course necessitie whiche chuse doe doe accordyng proprietie naturall disposition yet doe follow naturall inclination absolutely vnauoydeably god may hinder alter dispositiō make cease naturall operation kynde necessitie sinne say man clogged withall sith fall adam holy ghost grace absent selues sinne albeit let nature may bee holpen chaunged otherwise altered seé come passe regenerate christ necessitie therefore whereby wicked men sayd bee lead sinne absolute vnaduoydable chuse sinne assoone holy ghost grace christ commeth necessitie vtterly cut thus much internall necessitie necessitie spryngeth externall cause also deuided two maner wayes whereof one violentnecessitie coactiō called compulsary necessitie thyng forced moue styrre agaynst nature necessitie meanes fall man impossible shall thyng vnwillyngly stable infallible hypothesis reason consequence logician take sensu composito senfu diuiso necessitie called consequēce wise thyng may true occasiō necessary couplyng together one proposicion though thyng concluded true bee necessary selfe respect affirme action pelagius witte vse law consisteth two pointes principally say aduancyng vertue punishyng vyce hereupon osorius frame argument maner forme lawes ordeined vayne vnlesse habilitie performe themosori argument habilitie performe doctrine necessitie luther threache ergo lawes ordeined vayne luther doctrine necessitie aunswere maior proposition trueaunswere bondage necessitie doth preiudice habilitie naturall owne faultynesse say bene created without habilitie nature throwen selues inextricable laberinthe yelding owne default hauyng heaped vpon selues necessitie sinnyng voluntaryly owne purchase hauyng made necessitie augustine sayth penall offence good cause therefore lawes necessitie established may lawfull meane reduce v nature least reteyne v couenable order lyfenecessitie sinnyng imputed god selues ouerpassing also withall maior treateth obedience man lawes minor necessitie luther doth teach ought referred mās lawes discipline externall lyfe obediēce god law onely moreouer haue promised helpe vnderproppe osorius logicke selfe ruinous ready fall grounde refuse frame order forme remnaunt allegation argumentes reader may easily instructed aunswere make euery particularely argument osoriusthe freedome man beyng takē away force lawes preceptes rule good lyfe ordinaunces ciuill discipline statute cease necessitie luther teacheth doth abolish freedome man ergo doctrine necessitie allowed lawes decay good statute ordinaūces endeuour good godly lyfe extinguished aunswere freedome taken two wayesfirst maior proposition word freedome must distinguished namely taken either opposite coactiō opposite bondage maior vnderstād coacted freédome maior true whosoeuer taketh away freédome man doth also dispoyle vnderst̄ad bonde freédome euen meanes maior cleane false necessitie taken two maner wayesnext deny minor augustine wherein also word necessitie must distinguished whiche beyng deuided two partes one whiche called cōpul • ary necessitie whiche sayd consequence ex hypothesi wherof first • euer writer dyd deny none doctours deny whiche consistyng foreknowledge godthe necessitie luther teacheth doth take awaye fortune chaunce taketh awaye freedome certeine vnmoueable coniunction cause byndyng necessitie thyngs foreordeined god doth vtterly abolish fortune chaunce doth take away withstandeth freédome therof contradiction one selfe thyng may called uoluntary necessary also freédome taken away necessitie coaction example say god liueth euerlastyngly ordereth thynges vprightly doe confesse peculiar god nature necessitie forreine coactiō maner booke exod whereas pharao endeuour stay child israell departyng egypt must neédes confesse necessitie respect god secret appointemēt deéde neither could otherwisefreedome taken away coaction necessitie respect owne inclination peculiar nearest cause yt moued stay thē • necessitie coactiō forced vnwillingly uolūtaryly lesse earnest willingnes mynde bring passe ye thing greédy affection willed although man may constrayned somethyng many tymes agaynst yet framed meanes thyng yt would willeth called vnwillyngnesse nay rather nothyng cause bycause thyng course nature founde therfore hath denomination vsuall name speache whereby may expressed latine sorte also argumentes touchyng artes science whereof cauilleth much maner thynges happen bee referred power god done necessitie according luther doctrineosori argument pag 151 byndeth action men necessitie would hereupon follow science ouerthrowen endeuour mā vtterly frustrate industry mē neuer skilfull employed husbandry byeng sellyng traffique prouision familie surgery phisicke action man lyfe whatsoeuer shall profite auayleable aunswere bee truethe cōfutation operation thynges ought referred prouidence god chief principall cause whiche prouidence thynges ordered necessitie necessitie taketh away habilitie endeuour men causeth onely men action chaunceable albeit thyngs god willed doe necessaryly come passe yet doth man neuertheles yeld diligent endeuour prouidence god doth take away gouerneth deéde mās doth worke yea freély worketh say worketh voluntaryly coactly yet worketh god helpe worketh well god doe helpe worketh ill yet whether worke well ill alwayes worketh necessitie neither doth employ habilitie io • e lesse beyng gouerned god rather encouraged worke much earnestly bycause thynges come passe necessaryly whatsoeuer god hath foreordeined bee done industry man certes saying luther vndoubtedly true nothyng happeneth action man lyfe either well euill either without god knowledge without el without direction yet bycause success thynges vncerteine vnto v therefore followyng rule reason withall obeyeng god cōmaundeth v endeuour apply diligēce earnestly worke cōmending meane while selues successe trauaile tuitiō almighty god whose especiall commaundement thynges come end necessaryly obey direction necessitie wherby perceaue endeuours trauailes doe nothyng lesse decrease waxe dull worke bycause foreknowen directed god much encouraged worke bycause obey god cō maundeth worke therefore sophisme altogether sophisticall deceauable much vnlike whiche read origine second booke agaynst celsus sophister dissuade sicke body counsell phisickeorigene celsus 2 booke frameth argumēt thou predestinate sayth hee recouer health thou shalt surely hoale whether thou take phisicke thou predestinate dye phisition shall loase labour thou cast away thy money purpose sicke person perceauyng towardes mariadge lyke sophisme driuyng one nayle aunswereth maner thy destiny haue issue thy body thou shalt haue one whether thou marry wife marry wife thou predestinate childlesse thou shalt surely childies though thou marry wife neuer much deceite sophisme lurketh herein bycause endeuoursour actiōs must guded approued reason vncerteine certeinetie imagination ought depend vpō vncerteine certeintie whiche may applyable good euill indifferently vpon chaungeable aduenture successe wherof know must ordered direct assured rule reason albeit one side may come passe marryeth wife shall haue child yet part much impossible haue child without copulation man womā therfore ought yelded vnto seémed consonaunt reason ye argument concluded videl therfore must marry wife lyke maner fareth argument concernyng phisition although may come passe phisicke may helpe yet bycause agreable reason vnlesse phisicke ministred health bee recouered follow herein approued rule reason wilfully throw selfe vncerteine necessitie destiny whiche seémeth impossible least lesse agreable reason wherfore assumption false thou shalt vayne marry wife thou shalt vse phisicke vayne lyke maner aunswere osorius argument sophisticall hee argueth endeuours applyed vayne trauaile vayne well go foreward triflyng toyes sophister argument touchyng rewardes punishmentes much vertue vyce doe proceede free choyse willan suttle sophisme osorius opened pag 151 doth bereaue freedome must also dispoyle lyfe man due reward vertue punishment vyce luther byndyng thynges necessitie doth bereaue freedome ergo luther doctrine doth come passe neither punishment shalbe executed vpon malefactours vertue aduaunced condigne reward argument pelagius long • ithence vse agaynst august though selfe wordes yet one effect aunswere partes therof first concernyng freédome mentioned maior ought distinguished hath bene declared already minor respect kynde necessitie whiche forceth v yeld whether minor false touchyng reward vertue punishment vyce celestius pelagian vrged agaynst augustine wisethe obiectiō celestine pelagian agaynst augustine man blamed sayth committing sinne meanes auoyde augustine maketh aunswereaug aunswere nay rather sayth man therefore faultie hee without sinne bycause mās freewill onely came passe fall necessitie sinnyng necessitie owne withstād whereby perceaue osor necessitie sinnyng neither vtterly abolished frō mās nature malefactours duely punished notwithstādyng offence reason may iustified say sithence iudgement choyse whereby fall sinne freé subiect thraldome say thorough whose default seruitude came first already declared agayne whether offence committed frée seruile choyse maketh litle purpose quallyfieng punishment appeare iudge fact committed willfull corrupt lust affectiō say agayne offence voluntary obiection ergo therof consisteth owne power soeuer voluntary seemeth within compasse habilitie aunswereaunswere haue deéde naturally v well haue habilitie seluesaugust vpō wordes apostle • 2 sermon witte able well power soundenesse adā lost receaued abuse august epistle sixtusas touchyng rewardes aunswere albeit deédes deserue rewarded yet doth god righteously reward thē whenas doth crowne owne giftes v neither doth follow hereupon bycause god doth reward good workes v therfore good workes proceédyng frō v owne strength habilitie bycause hath vouchsaued make giftes bycause powreth good giftes v therefore worthely good giftes rewarded owne yet neither reward geuē due desert respect worthynes worke gracious liberalitie hath bountyfully powred vpon v vndeserued make v obedient vnto briefly aunswere though selfe playne manifest shall seéme small credite bryng augustine umpyer betwixt v sufficient enough trust beyng long agoe assayled obiections pelagians shall better maintenaunce owne credite fully aūswere cauillations heretiques like vnto selfe pelagiās obiect agaynst sort true thynges frō begynnyng determined end god foreordinaunce decreécelestius pelagian augustine mēs willes directed god purpose lawes made punishment ordeined malefactours men rebuked reproued reprehended accused haue receaued maruell disobediēt god whē commaūdeth obey hath geuen obey euen augustine hath aunswered obiection long sithence let osorius cōtent selfe aūswered wordesaugust de corr • pt grat cap 6 correcting vyce sayth punishment ministred two cause first bycause man euill owne default euill worketh euill voluntaryly owne accorde although ought doubted mās ought subiect god mā let worke best liketh much listeth frameth man worke yet cause contrary man receaue due punishement offence selfe committeth willfully seyng worker owne sinne man sinneth agaynst cause transgressours worthely punished bycause trespassours either regenerate beyng cleansed fallyng agayne former filthe owne accorde pleade defence neuer receaued grace men freewill haue made frustrate grace god receaued owne wickednesse regenerate yet damnable originall sinne worthely punished anguish punishment may conceaue desire regenerate least man chastized child promise god outward vsing meane scourge vexation chastizement may secret inspiration fashion frame obedience c thus much hetherto cōcernyng lawes ordinaūces rewardyng vertue punishyng vyce ciuill gouernement followeth absurditie witte sayth luther doctrine man altogether dispoyled vnderstandyng depriued iudgement bereft reason driuē extremitie better naturall stoane throwen man hand osorius argument osor cauill pag 151whosoeuer attribute orderyng thynges absolute necessitie exemptyng freedome doe spoyle men vnderstandyng depriue iudgement bereue reason trāfforme brute beastes stoanes luther doctrine doth bynde men action willes necessitie ergo luther doctrine doth dispoyle mē sens turneth stoanes aunswerei deny maior argument minor distinguish word necessitie lastly argument altogether vicious two cause either bycause osorius thinkethosori double errour necessitie byndeth thynges directed eternall prouidence ordinaunce god el supposeth necessitie must neédes exclude freédome false first touchyng necessitie luther aūcient writer learnedly affirmeall thyngs subiect god prouidence action man lyfe subiect fortune herein acknowledge prouidence god assigne onely principall gouernesse guide mās lyfe directeth mās purpose boweth bendeth ordereth enterprise thereof moreouer teach prouidence whiche whirled blynd sudden motion wherein place left happenynges fortune prouidence must neédes depend vpon inferiour causeschaunceable thinges • destiny fortune chaūce excluded beyng cause action vpon necessary couplyng together cause wherein destiny excluded prouidence vnaduisedly vncerteinly tossed fro accordyng wandryng chaunces fortune wherein fortune chaunce taken away prouidence consisteth certeine assured stedfast permanent orderthe order superiour inferiour cause workyng meane while inferiour mixte cause neuerthelesse though tyed cause necessary bonde couplyng may possibly doe otherwise owne absolute freé motione neither though cause could possibly doe otherwise must necessitie follow direction prouidence whereunto subiect whereby commeth passe freewill beyng occupyed meane causesfreewill neither altogether bōd altogether free neither ceaseth altogether freé forced forreine constraint guided owne accord yet remayneth absolutely freé constrayned whether wil yeld ye direction god prouidence voluntaryly notwithstandyng coactly wherupon amongest learned necessitie called necessitas immutabilitatis aut certitud • ni necessitie vnchangeable certeintie whiche though doe vrge thynges violent coaction yet much nothyng al creation nature small substance without cōpasse god knowledgein respect god prouidence thynges done necessitie chaunce therfore albeit many thing seéme accordyng capacity done chaunce yet respect god prouidence wee duely consider originall principall cause thynges done wee shall finde nothing done could done necessitie make hast absurdity witte osorius friuolous brabblynges sorte crawleth man lawes ciuill gouernement god lawes arguyng sort nothing auayleable good lyfe selfe nothyng sinne god lawes commaunded vayne vayne also exhortatiōs aduertisementes ministred vayne blessinges cursinges set downe scripturesobiection argument taken frō preceptes exhortatiōs god law pag 15 • man wil say cōmaūded scripture vayne ergo doctrine luther false execrable whereby leaueth none habilitie freewill onely sinne whereby bindeth thing necessity aunswere august de gratia libero arbit cap 16this maior must bee denyed beyng nothyng el manifest cauillation witte tendyng effect though god commaunded v doe nothyng might owne selues performe whereunto augustine aunswereth wise man commaundemēt learne thou oughtest doe punishment learne thy weakenesse thyne owne default prayer learne whence thou mayest obteyne c law commaundyng forebyddyng therefore accordyng augustine come knowledge sinne infirmitie owne strength power yet seéme chaūceable necessary meanes bereft freédome vnlesse paraduenture bycause god seyng man wil inclinable wickednesse doth restrayne may cause may sayd take away freédome withstandeth disputation distinguished god yt haue relation ye god hath discouered selfe vnto v expresse law ye schoolemen tearme voluntatē sigui argue wise god righteous ergo sinner god righteousnesse selfe ergo sinne partly procurement sathan partly frayltie nature man defile owne voluntary fall whereupon sayth cause euill sought ought seéke el selues whole blame therof must lay vpon selues luther caluines doctrine true agreable touchyng cause sinne say wordes caluine agree luther doctrine seing luther maketh god authour good euill caluine maketh man cause euill nay rather meanes forge vnto v crafty deuise iarryng vniforme agreement iudgemēt betwixt luther caluine caluine supposeth cause euill ought sought el man luther teacheth righteousnesse ought sought el god onely felowes either go make man either coupled together altogether sundered frō ye confesse ye sufferaunce ioyned together god sayd either suffer thyng whiche willeth thyng wherof selfe certeine maner cause sunder sufferaunce god wherein luther doth discourse vpon necessitie agaynst mainteynours chaūce fortune cā denyed god prouidence gouernement present tyme foreknowledge thynges come wayes deceaueable side wt gorgeous whole practize herein thē august long sithence worthely reprehēd cicero witte while striue much make v free practize nothyng el make v horrible blasphemours withall endeuour vndermyne vnpenetrable castell god foreknowledge able foretell thynges come neuer knew preuente assured certeintie success thyngs without vtter subuersion infallible prouidence god foreknowledge wherfore would wishe well aduised osorius least while thinke molest luther outragious barkyng affirmyng infallible necessitie flowyng aboue founteine deuine operation direction thyngs ye fall selfe headlong last cōbersomenot striue agaynst luther warre agaynst god hymselfe gulfe adiudged 〈 nonlatin alphabet 〉 playnly 〈 nonlatin alphabet 〉 beyng able endure doctrine necessitie ye entangle selfe vnto inextricable maze impietie ye shalbe thought practise abādonyng vndeceueable certeintie god sacred scripture heauen example fine cicero while ye affect cicero much nymblenesse stile el gathered detestable discourse cicerocicereos discourse agaynst god prouidence detestable august calleth execrable opiniō osor ye man seémes thing auoyded god doth know shall come passe assuredly necessitie must graunted doctrine prouidence necessitie beyng excluded god prouidence also rent asunder withall maner doth cicero dispute bookes de natura deorum cicero de natur deor lib 2 thynges come saith foreknowen must neédes followe euery thyng must proceéde due order much nothyng done without cause therfore must due order knittyng together cause graunted necessitie whereupō must neédes ensue yt thynges yt done performed vnauoydeable necessitie graunted sayth ciuill societie rooted lawes established vayne correction praysing dispraysing good counsell ministred vayne neither anye ordinaunce deuised aduauncement vertue punishement vyce serueth purpose allaugust de ciuitat dei 5 booke cap 9 bycause haynous daungerous absurdity tollerable weale publique therfore sayth augustine man yeld foreknowledge thyngs come meanes forceth reader inconueniences chuse one two either man force el thynges must determined vpon necessitie beyng opinion one tyme together one allowed must needes abolished leane vnto god foreknowledge prouidēce must freewill haue place side mainteyne freewill foreknowledge thyngs come must banished ye while cicero beyng otherwise man wōderful experience august sayth endeuoureth make v freé doth bring v wtin ye cōpasse sacrilege horrible robber god foreknowledge beyng ignoraunt selfe vnite freédome foreknowledge together rather suffreth god despoyled wisedome men left destitute freewill errour augustine doth worthely reproue himaug de ciuitat dei lib 5 cap 9 therfore good consequent bycause well orderyng dispositiō cause hand god man freewill therfore made fruitelesse altogether willes selues cause humaine action exempt frō well disposed order cause alwayes vnchaungeable god directed prouidence therfore wisedome doth cōprehend cause al thyngs also cause selues could ignoraunt willes foreknow cause al doyngs go let v compare blynd philosophy cicero diuinitie osorius respectes bussardlyke cicero doth vphold freédome man ouerthrow god prouidence predestination contrarywise ouerthrow man freewill doth gather establish certeintie god prouidence supposing stand together lyke maner osorius imaginyng selfe perpetuall vnappeasable disagreément betwixt necessitie orderyng cause man freewill meanes may argreé together doth meane el thē pursuyng platteforme cicero builded couplyng cause come issue length either establish doctrine necessitie luther agreéyng cicero vtterly roote foreknowledge prouidēce godaug booke chap chuse propertie thynges done necessitie accordyng osorius opinion agayne necessitie perpetuall orderyng cause ciceroes suppositiō perpetuall order cause neither perpetuall order thynges foreknowledge god come passe operation cause precedenta suttle sophisme practizyng persuade meere absurdity perpetuall orderyng thynges foreknowledge god thē thyngs atteyne ye success wherunto ordeyned agayne thyngs atteyne success whereunto ordeyned god foreknowledge thynges come let v cōpare first suttle sophisme last execrable conclusionthe choise man free ergo god foreknowledge thynges come let osorius aduise selfe well aunswere make argument hold ciceroes opinion remayneth hee must neédes condemne v sacrilege cicero doth while endeuoureth make v freé know hee wil hold case deéde ciceroes argument ought allowed doth discende directly argument frō proper cause proper effectes whereas freewill mainteyned one propositiō cause wherefore denyed thynges done necessitie also good consequent lykewise bycause necessitie taught consiste vnchaūgeable orderyng cause god foreknowledge therfore nothyng remayneth effectual freewill suttletie sophisme disclosed bycause agreéyng herein augustine doe confesse witte aswell god doth know thynges done cause ye thynges foreknowen done necessitieaugust de ciuit dei lib 5 cap 9 also willyngly worke whatsoeuer know feéle done v without owne consentes reply luther contrary augustine doctrine leaue man lyfe altogether destitute freewill tyeng action fast bounde chaynes vnauoydeable necessitie aunswere luther doth defend euery absolute vnaduoydeable necessitieluther doth neither teache euery necessitie absolutely take away freedome men whiche spake consequence doth take away freédome neither men freédome onely set contrary opposite spirituall bondage yet doth exempt men freédome onely regenerate better grace christ iesu whosoeuer inueste person freédome vtter enemy grace lesse false also whatsoeuer coūterfaite deuine doth groūde selfe vpon hath hundred tymes vrged touchyng opinion necessitie wise brauleth agaynst luther caluine thyngs doe done meere necessitie decreed vpon furthest end eternitie surely whatsoeuer wickednesse committe lead owne voluntary motion drawen perpetuall constraynte bee adiudged sinne triflyng sophisme haue vtterly crusht peéces authoritie augustine neither came euer myndes luther caluine mainteyne necessitie cōpulsary externall coaction enforce committe wickednesse vnwillyngly man sinneth sinneth voluntaryly albeit none action destitute certeyne perpetuall directiō almighty lord gouernour yea though neither sinnes selues altogether escape prouident foreknowledge god yet peruerse frowardnesse wicked thyng lesse excusable ought receaue cōdigne punishment accordyng wicked deseruynges whosoeuer hath voluntaryly offended deserueth punished therfore herein osorius friuolous diuinitie doth litle bewray nakednesse whereas debatyng matter sinne seémeth haue learned lesson yet augustine sinne punishmēt sinne oneaugust de natur grat cap 22 therfore mainteynyng one lye doth conclude wisely agreable equitie sithence men instrumentes onely god worker thyngs condemned malefactours onely instrumentes good reason sworde wherewith man slayne adiudged faultie persō slue man swordosorius pag 152 whiche selfe would deny agaynst reason yt matter osor would applye euer speake dreame men instrument onely doyng wickednesse god authour worker mischief ye wordes osorius luther caluines answere false diuinitie osoriusthat wicked men sawes instrumentes many tymes handes god punishement sinne luther onely esay also doth boldly confesse go therfore cōclude men nothyng el instrument tooles onely wisely warraunt deriuyng argument propositiō exponent exclusiue nay rather maliciously wrestyng peruertyng thynges truth slaunderous cauillyng august doth sundry tymes witnesse men willes subiect god able withstand itaug de correp grat cap 14 much willes selues sayth god doth fashion liketh lysteth willes auayleable god willed foresawe bee auayleable august de ciuitat dei lib 5 cap 9 whereby seé god almighty power doth worke willes workeshoppe whē purposeth thyng doth neither trāspose willes otherwise purpose ye seruice owne willes yet doth therfore follow ye men willes nothyng el iustrumentes tooles onely god handyworke ye thyng selfe doth nothyng carryed whirled hither thither without proper motiō operation agent cause onely truly augustine sayth wellaug de peccatis meritis lib 2 cap 5 doe worke wishinges onely sayth least hereupon cauillation arise effectuall procure lyue well bycause god doth worke saluation v vnsensible stoanes thynges nature created voyde reason c deéde god doth worke willes hart men yet rollyng tossyng stoanes driuyng whirlyng thynges without lyfe though enterprising attemptyng thynges myndes willes men carryed forrein constraint deuine coaction without voluntary motion intelligible mynde therfore osorius doth hereof friuolously falsely forge cankred cauillation maliciously practizeth procure doctrine luther maligned though deuise man lyke vnto stoane imagined god onely authour worker mischief oso caui • bycause teach men willes subiect god wil secundary cause certes • august writeth begraūted truth god cause thynges done august hys treatise vpon gen agaynst manichaeus lib 1 cap 2 lesse alowable luther false eche respect aug since speake one selfe sentence one iudgement therein neither therfore good consequent osor doth phantasie onely god cause sinne though man nothyng reproueable sinnyng punishable deseruyng end tendeth whole cutted conclusion osorius brabblynges haue skill know nature distinctiō yet must taught one thyng permitte sinne voluntar • ly thyng committe sinne voluntaryly wherof first proper god peculiar men first may done without offence bee done meanes without wickednesse whereas god sayd sinne certeyne maner sayd done accordyng call god good pleasure neither euill without truth scripture yet followeth hereupon necessaryly god onely proper cause sinnehow cause called onely proper cause accompted onely cause excludeth cause besides selfe cause called proper cause doth respect onely one end yea also last end respect wherof accompted proper cause whereas therfore sinne ye last end god man peruersenesse affirme done deéde without god man proper cause therof god cause thynges must proportioned endes surely sinne ye last end god respect euill respect ye scourge plague sinne speake paules propheticall scripture haue mercy haue mercy make euident paule debateth matter manner therefore sayth god doth take mercy taketh mercy doth hardē hardē though might say god choosing refusing hys creature tyed necessitie neyther law ye contrary yt may according good pleasure therin liketh lusteth dochoose thee yu hast great cause thākfull vnto cast theé yu hast iust cause quarrell wt hym therfore doth yt wrong thy god thy potter art yu cōtend wt weake man wt thy mighty god lump clay ye potter effect argumētthe reason osorius touchyng cause order predestination surely god willeth foreknowe would worke wickednes also predestinate iacob become lord elder brother foreknow taht work would proue good therfore saying apostle false work c imediatly enterlacing many thinges betweene graunt quoth man may chosen refused thing yet god foresee would followeth hereupon might haue chosen worthines workes god foresaw would though yet done nothing saying yet borne preuayle thee spoken elder shall serue younger declare hereby sayde workes yet wrought nothing c let passe august let v heare paule himselfe speaketh debating largely vpon poynt predestination doth amongst last breake speach touching samerom 9 god willing one side shewe wrath make power knowen hath great sufferaunce lenity borne vessel wrath prepared destruction side make knowne rich glory towardes vessel mercy hath prepared glory c let v exactly ponder wordes apostlethe word paul expounded sayth god willing therein heare first god doth withall cause reason willeth ye perceiue expresly set downe afterwardes sayd wrath yt say willing shew seueritie iustice pray towardes towardes creature indifferently certes might haue done according iustice would mercy sake towards thē towardes vessells wrath prepared vnto destruction heare name vessell doe withall conceaue potter bycause vessells made without potter moreouer worde prepared annexed thereby forthwith commeth remembraunce potter thyng fashioned standeth power port selfe fashion forme selfe owne fashioning therof resteth purpose potter sense feélyng earthen vessells would vessell fashion selfe vessell dishonour power fashion selfe meanes vessell houour whereupon followeth consequently order disposition fashionyng resteth wholy potter vessell therfore concernyng potter left mā shall thinke vnaduised directed equitie reason apostle doth forthwith set downe cause therewith mouth slaunderous backbyter may stopped shew sayth rich glory towardes vessel mercy hath prepared vnto glory c doth say bycause god foresaw good workes godly euill doynges wicked therfore ordeyned dā nation chosen saluation hee sayth prepared destruction would haue vessells wrath others glory yet notwtstandyng neither vnaduisedly contrary equitie wherein man desirous know ye reason iustice god predestination let heare augustine herein whole masse mankinde subiect sayth one state perdition rightly deseruyng scourge god iustice august ad simplici lib 1 quaest 2 whether executed pardoned proceedeth vnrighteousnesse god pleased god good mercy make choyse relinquish accordyng iustice require reason hereof apostle doth hyde make knowen sayth rich glory willeth runneth god taketh mercy contrary part meane shipwrack damnation man wayward peruersnes beyng left vnto self doth therin throughly play partes yt nothing wherewt may iustly accuse god neyther whereas man doth commit euillmalum culpae malum poenae punished euill let hym thank hymself whereas righteously punished herein let murmure god though author euill righteously done vnorderly done god create hys creature destructiō vntrue god doth condemne nothing hys owne nature sinne onely god created man first created hym perfect vprightthe originall sinne ascribed vnto creature vnto creatour without sinne indued also freé absolute abilitie sinne thē armed hym sufficiēt furniture agaynst sinne witte especiall admonitiō matter doth sufficiently declare selfe god make man perish saued afterwardes sinne began bud taking sappe thereof god sathangod dyd create man ende perish freéwill man wherupon immediatly ensued damnation layed vpon man shoulder reason creation willingly purchased reason owne sinne adam stood fast vprightnes wherein created god condemned hym beyng vprightnes might haue bene cause peraduenture might haue moued iust complaynt god hys bare decreé vniustly created hys owne creature end damned sithence whole race mankinde cast selfe vnderfoote default hys lust god default good aunswere questiō god make hys creature vnto destruction creature selfe defiling selfe sinne contrary dignitie hys creationfrō whēce cause damnation sprang first hath made selfe abhominable vgly chaungeling transformed selfe creature god creature serpēt creator destroying hys creature may well adiudged haue condemned creature made creature sathan serpent destroyed say image god deformed soone created know whose default god default man default good creator custody lord daunger settyng god commaundement naught whenas chose rather become bondslaue sathan aspyring wise creator god god iustice doe bounden carefull bodyes seruaūt yet god mercy forsake yeld whatsoeuer called god yet pretely shake pluckt vysours apish stager discouered fraude made ye world acquaynted subtill sleyghtes lyeng doctrine confuted manifest force truth finally albeit openyng light gospell could vtterly • ende peéces shryne beast many hūdred yeares suppressed drowned darkenes knowledge god word yet industry labour vnprofitably employed defacyng therof would god bene able onely haue defaced power outrage ye seé also haue plucked vppe rootes brought memory therof vtter confusion vanished cleane ye myndes memoryes men nation euer doyng truly could haue done exployte acceptable god profitable state christianitie certes many thousandes men womē bene wonderfully preserued thereby barbarous vnspeakeable cruelty consumyng gulfe haue bene miserably swallowed vppe deuoured within yeares englād fraunce spayne scotland flaunders germany christian nation yet vnsatiable cormoraūt sufficiētly englutted fully gorged christiā goare yet thisthe wolfe doth accuse lambe troublyng water poore seély luther accused durst boldly presume vnlade cure christiā conscience cancred fistula poysoned impostume raunging carbuncle bycause dare vndertake patronadge defence truth agaynst manifest heresy palpable errours lesse layed charge hygh treason though practized vtter ouerthrowe onely christian societie state whole world also may wolfe wt good reason condenme seély selfe like vnto seemeth haue happened luther wherewith read ye wicked achab charge elia ye prophet euē like deceitfull maner3 kyngs saying thou art quoth doest trouble israell much vnlike example nero whereof history make mention hauyng himselfe sett roome fire playing singing vpon hys harpe destruction thereof homer verse while flame afterwardes lay burning thereof christian charge thend might procure though altogether innocent maligned hated persequuted people euen lyke maner osorius whenas ye papistes generatiō holy father haue long sithence tourned state whole worlde conditiōs absolute necessitie must god accompted onely author workes thinges whether good badde thinges good euill ordered guyding god author thereof remayneth nothing man freewill put execution graunted followeth hereupon men rushed headlong mischiefes cō mit wickednes owne accord tooles instrumentes wickednesse plyed thereunto others hand enforced merueilous coaction proposition thus argued luther godaugust de trinitat lib 3 god sayth first soueraigne cause formes motion nothing done issueth fromout secrett intelligible closett highest emperour according vnspeakeable iustice doth omnipotent wisedome god worke pleaseth hym mightely stretcheth hys power one ende worlde ordereth thinges sweetely thus much augustine necessitie coaction yet cause doth therefore enduce necessitie coactione ought punished asmuch luther assertion doth maintayne none become horrible accusation wherein luther sayd accuse god vnrighteousnesse agreable iustice sayth onely instrumentes wickednesseosori pag 163 punished according luther doctrine men wickedly seeme nothing el instrumentes wickednes finde doctour haue euer besides osorius spake wise either waking sleéping sometime god prouidence doth vse seruice man punish euill doer euen god auenge hym vpon sinnes owne people babilonianes agayne take vengeaunce assirianes cirus duke persia raysed vppe god vse also malice iewes finish worke redemption vnlesse natione conspired agaynst sonne god bene redeémed deuill himselfe rodde correction hand god instrument vengeaunce ordayned punishe outragies euill doer yet doth therefore follow deuils wicked persones called instrumentes god wrath nothing el instrumentes though forced onely themselues nothing though doyng nothing themselues deserued wrath neyther imagine mē like vnto stoanes haue sayd though left vnto abilitie actionno mā sinneth without god contrary god euen mynde man vnlesse ayded selfe nothing sinne doth man sinne tyme hys owne voluntary motione sinne albeit doth commit without god yet doth commit contrary commaundement god acquired hys fault murtherer killeth men albeit seeme certeine maner exe • uute god yet doth deede onely beyng minde simply serue hys god rather follow rage malice therfore neyther excusable beyng faulty god accused vnrighteous executeth hys wrath wherfore false slaunderous osorius doth conclude vpon assertion predestination cōcluded two absurdity second inferiour cause gouerned although condemnation reprobate without decreé yet neuerthelesse condemnation adiudged righteous floweth also properly properly frō decreé god many thinges done vnrighteousnes god protagoristes diagoristes men farre wicked preache much aunswere shall frame malapere currishe slaunderinge iemini2 kyng 16 god haue cōmaunded lye shamelesly without controlement backbite vertuous personage sort remayneth patiently endure generall grief godly recomfort thē selues example dauid peraduenture lord behold affliction render vnto good thinges cursed slaunder meane space one thyng delighteth little whereas fellow doth counterfayte lye thinges yet doth openly man choose laugh hym withall impudently euery man may detest hynm agayne blockishly euery man may despise deryde wherby commeth passe doth much preiudice luther euill speaking doth bewray hys owne ignoraunce worlde worsse prouing hys false forged lye seeing heé hath neyther seemed haue learned thinge truth yet proued lye hath forged euer shalbe able proue go gaine think ye haue made slaunders lye ye accuse luther amongest nūber atheistes diagoristes protagoristes farre wicked also one doth condemne god vnrighteousness affirmeth author euill dispoyleth man iudgement reason bryngeth fatall necessitie excludyng action operation compelleth men wickedly agaynst willes teacheth men may freely euill go vnpunished couereth naughtines excuse vnspeakeable treachery ye lay luther charge ye beleue ye shall make man geue credite talke doe ye think one ryse vppe vpon sodayne readyng luther bookes espye thys manifest falshood lying let euery man peruse luther writinges ouer ouer hath left behynde hym pledge testimonyes hys fayth hath euer iudged written honorably god iustice hath euer vehemency reproued man vnrighteousnes condēned sharpely farre shadowyng wickednes naughtipackes cloude excuse hath thys man affirmed god author euill doth tye men necessitie sinnyng necessitie especially osori dreameth doth affirme nature left destitute grace cānot sinne necessitie necessitie notwithstādyng proceedeth frō el frō selfe beyng corrupted osori doth snatch wrest sentēce cauillation though luther bryng necessitie leaue freédome man moreouer necessitie abolish libertie though could vndertake nothing voluntary choyse forced whirled thinges • oaction constraint indifferency vseth osorius aunswere vnto maior two maner wayes first true deéde lawes whiche established lawgeuer onely ende subiectes exactly performe albeit god desire thyng chiefly men precisely throughly obserue ordinaunces yet besides consideration many endes causesthe vse end law 1 iudgement wrath god agaynst sinne made manifest 2 might easily brought acknowledgemēt sinnes weakenesse 3 thyrdly vnderstandyng weakenes feéle selues heauyly oppressed burden sharpely prouoked schoolemaisters rodde fleé vnto christ end law 4 schoolyng may learne way ought take geuen v least atteyne full absolute obedience law yet begynnyng obedient may profitte much may secundaryly confesse maior true respect lawes due obseruation cause cōtrary either lawgeuer nature selfe appeareth rather subiectes whose onely fault disorderous licentiousnes procureth breach therof example prince sende foorth ambassadour respectes whole sounde well enstructed afterwardes geueth commaundement put matter execution might easily bryng passe vnlesse owne default disorder made selfe lame halte vnable execute commaundement prince ambassadour want health strēgth become vnable execute embassie ought ye prince blamed ambassadour rather owne folly hath disabled selfe augustine doth seéme emply booke de perfectione iustit august de perfect iustit nay rather cause sayth man blameworthy perfittly doe duetie liue without sinne bene made perfect fallen therefore nature beautified supernaturall giftes spoiled naturall power abilitie remayning force notwithstanding vntrue whereas nature selfe alteration substaunceaunswere accesse sinne disposition depraued reuolted god weakened spoyled operation yt may conuerted onely grace god hauing self part thys work farre forth preuented god whereupon augustine doth witnes doth goe handmayd well doyng wherefore nature substaunce remayneth still chaunged new shape god creation defiled corruption filthe nature affection also remayne respect substaūce respect disposition putrified stincking nothing found bringeth matter filthines soeuer holpen doth worke somewhat together hym helpeth hymobiect suffereth self applyed meerely passiuely beyng renued holpen grace ergo freewill euen sithence first creation seemeth bring much passe altogether applyed passiuely maior proposition haue bene added perse selfe aunswere soeuer worketh selfe hauing help altogether plyed passiuely exception minor must denyed freedome choyse selfe neuer preuenteth grace following altogether holpen grace goyng according testimony augustine bryng passe selfe thing selfe whiche able doe doth morall good thinges externall ciuill exercise certes deserue eternall lyfe purchase fauour god saluation iustification euerlasting kingdome freéwill altogether vneffectuall meere sufferer onely hath thing hath receaued altogether vnprofitable yea hath done possibly luther seemeth stand vpon let hym accursed say god commaundeth thynges impossibleout ierome melancton doth aunsweremelanchtones consequent would goodaunswere circumstance beyng altered state conclusion altered also action man life gouerned disposition secret prouidence god true man also doth endeuour withall together therefore operation working partes god worketh man worketh one matter bicause god doth order thing farre meanes respecting ende men doe herein redowndeth vnto hym highest commendation power iustice aud bounty men worthely blamed beyng cause harmes ioseph solde hys brother iudas betrayed lord absalon defiled hys father concubine pharao witheld people israell semei rayled vpon dauid antiochus waxed wrothe agaynst iewes long sithence whenas antichrist euen gryndeth hys teeth agaynst seély flock christ paule breathed threatninges slaughter man deny haynous horrible factes notwithstanding one wanted singuler counsell god hys especiall prouidence whereupon could possible otherwise thinges determined come passe ende neyther doth enter man thought thing god doth mā shoulde neither doth man purpose thinge foreseéne foreordained god thē shall therefore accuse god author wickednesse vngodly thinges chaunce necessitie god hath purposed shall come passe meanes altered seemeth osori conclude hys argument argue agaynst hym wise two reason first preordinaunce god whereof speake bryng necessitie externall coaction vppon men osorius doth speake man could sinne voluntaryly cōpelled thereunto god might seeme altogether perhaps purpose impute fault thereof god mā hath euer bene horribly wicked time performing treacherous deuises say constrayned agaynst hys commit facte would haue done neyther led thereunto motion selfe blynded hys owne affection moreouer although god doth work together man willaug de grat lib arb cap 21 augustine liked rather speake whether god worke harte men apply willes whervnto pleaseth hym eyther godlines hys good mercy sake wickednes vyce according owne deseruinges whether man afflicted crosse persequution yet doth god bring passe according iust iudgement sometimes open manifest alwayes righteous sitteth iustice thē punish offender tame suppresse outragious pryde rebellious nature forasmuch workes god directed chiefly one ende whence may man take large occasion magnifie extoll iustice god hys owne work therefore though weé confesse one selfe work wrought god man yet selfe worke god worketh way ende namely putting vre worke hys iustice men workes pryde luste wrath couetousnes hereupon commeth passe sinne worthely imputed vnto god remayning alwayes righteous good notwithstanding rule holden alwayes vnshaken work god wrought best fall first parent adam hardening pharaoes hart treasō iudas persequutiō paule tended good purpose perseueraunce noah fayth humblenes dauid peter denyall hys maister conuersion paule soeuer wrought god doth alwayes tourne glorifiing hys power magnifieng hys iustice hys iustice sinne doth punish sinne righteously hys power whē hys mighty hand onstretched arme doth aduaunce deliuer wonderfull mercy sake hys free liberalitie pleaseth hym vouchsaue osorius wylypye destitute starting hoale seéke escape chynk moushoole doth perceaue god power cānot vtterly sequestred action men like olde tryed shifter collour matter applye workes god haue rehearsed god foreknowledge subtill distinction whereunto aduersaryes flee defence aduersaries dally god prouidencethey say prouidence god may enduce attayne knowledge good euil came passe iuste iudgement god hys permission hys prouidence also freewill beyng throughly furnished vnderstanding reason destitute grace could gouerne selfe must needes iudgemēt hidden deéde alwayes iust leadyng directyng thynges ende whereby may make iustice power discernable mankynde end word counsells god effectes tende directed whether fashion vessel wrath destruction prepare vessel mercy glory whether mercyfull whether harden harte pleaseth hym whensoeuer pleaseth doth styrre vppe myndes endeuoures men unto lysteth seruice sathan minister wrath whether comfort make glad harte chosen operatiō holy ghost yet cause meane while man complayne thynges done iniuriously done god secrete iudgement god ought blamed whenas whatsoeuer done beleue assuredly done either expresse power make glory discernable commend iustice el discouer wonderfull rich mercy wherfore luther doth affirme god thynges done absolute necessitie whether come destiny chaunce fortune lawfull speake osorius speake lyke phrase lyke title word god necessitie ye best iust wisest heare sounde argument popish diatriba obiect diatriba others agaynst luther say abridge god power neither would tyme otherwise selfe hath abridged although nothyng omnipotency god bryng passe yet would haue nothyng lawfull selfe might contrary iustice bycause horrible matter man damned without euill deseruynges reason good workes defrauded due reward therfore must needes follow accordyng rule iustice god chuse thē would haue saued good workes whiche forsee condemne lykewise euill doynges otherwise doe regarde workes iustice constaunt permanent obiection must ouertaken maneraunswere one thyng treate god election thyng treate iudgement concernyng iudgement god euident man damned vnlesse haue deserued wickednesse man saued vnlesse matter founde whereunto saluation may imputed farre otherwise election predestination accomplished accordyng god freé determination coūsell without respect grat cap • workes calleth elder shall serue younger doth say workes done apostle spake generally workes would men vnderstand workes done already past workes yet done say workes past none workes done yet done c workes therfore haue tyme place certes electiō haue neither tyme place neither thyng value onely god neither dependeth vpon fayth vpon workes vpō promise workes fayth promise whatsoeuer exceédyng mercy obiect osori pag 163euen one man kill sworde man doth therfore accuse sword rather knowen faulte abuse sword murther good reason asmuch men nothyng el instrumentes wickednesse onely consent owne god royster hackster would delight slaughter men similitude altogether mislyked graunt vnto will men directed subiect stronger power able resiste yet suffer onely instrument brutish senselesse nothyng selues meane while men drawen deéde owne will augustine maketh mention neither man euill selfe man owne accord euill ought blamed therfore selfe shall say sinne founde committe crooked conueyaunce false slaūderous cauillations wherein many others turmoyle themselues much doth porting ouer greedely busye hymselfe rest cauillacions aduersaries wherewith impugne doctrine predestination altogether vnprofitable superfluous edification iustitution good lyfe vse obiectthe reason wherwith aduersaries doe practise suppresse verye name predest meanes doctrine predestinatiō carefulnes takē away frō mē fallē ryse agayn stand occasion sluggishnes ministred man trauaile altogether superfluous respectes neyther woūded cānot able become sound agayn hys owne industry neyther chosen fall away negligence one whereof desperation nourished slouthfulnes mayntayned thing first decreed vpon god hys vnchaungeable counsell predestination neede thē preaching godly exhortation whereby men affection may eyther stirred vp embrace vertue terrified frōtheir accustomable licēciousnes life whenas desperate minde shall think selfe wise whether lyue well otherwise shalbe notwithstanding length god foreknow good good euill euill forasmuch therefore teaching thys doctrine sinewes endeuour brust asunder remayneth certayne fatall necessity onely say conuenient haue wordes speach matter add moreouer superfluous dispute matter depth whereof neuer man able reache vnto thing nothing fitte instructiō auditorye besides true yet ought taught say deliuereth matter perniciouse receaued thinges able conceaued may without daunger holden couert moreouer want dayes defend obstinacye auncientye forasmuch auncient father eyther wryte nothing el litle thereof teach grace preuenting merites holy one farre otherwise wherfore would haue people taught wise rather god hys goodnes mercye would haue men saued cause saued receaue grace indifferently offered vnto maner teaching suppose sound contrary doctrine predestinatiō doth take cleane away force vse wholesome preachinges exhortation discipline c answere obiect proposed onely eyther alone first vrged slaunders cauillationes lesse cause wōder ye wickednes age seé new thinge neuer spoken thinge many notable learned men haue bene sundry tymes combred withall long sithence emongest cō meth first hand augustine beyng occupyed thys cause sometyme pelagianes massilianes molest much obiectiones appeareth playnely transcript prosper hillary letter augustine euen obiections deuines dayes pressed withall true might seeme haue vndertaken quarrell rashly altogether vayne men haue done also let v aunswere complayntes doctrin predestination maner moderation ought preached peoplesuch appoynted teacher
